snippet.description:
During a year in the Museum’s Science Research Mentoring Program, two high school students discover more than just new lab skills: they discover a new species of anemone. See how Elena and Sebastian’s project analyzing some of the invertebrate collections at the American Museum of Natural History taught them how to be scientists and helped contribute to a scientific discovery.

For a visual cue transcript, visit: http://www.amnh.org/explore/amnh.tv/(watch)/learning-at-the-museum2/analyzing-anemones-students-discover-new-species/(category)/131055
 
The Science Research Mentoring Program (SRMP) offers high school students the opportunity to join ongoing research projects lead by AMNH scientists. Learn more about the program, and apply, here: http://www.amnh.org/learn-teach/grades-9-12/science-research-mentoring-program/

Support for the Science Research Mentoring Program at the American Museum of Natural History is provided by Christopher C. Davis; The Shelby Cullom Davis Charitable Fund; The Pinkerton Foundation; the Bezos Family Foundation; the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation; the Solon E. Summerfield Foundation; Inc.; and the Adolph and Ruth Schnurmacher Foundation.

This video and all media incorporated herein (including text, images, and audio) are the property of the American Museum of Natural History or its licensors, all rights reserved. snippet.title: Analyzing Anemones: Students Discover New Species

snippet.description:
As a participant in the Museum's Science Research Mentoring Program (SRMP), high school junior Gavriela Carver spends up to four hours each week during the school year working in a Museum science lab. 

Under the guidance of Jairo Arroyave, a Department of Ichthyology postdoctoral fellow, Gavriela works on a project studying the evolutionary relationships within a large multi-family clade of catfishes. Eventually, her analysis of DNA-sequence data will be incorporated into a research paper slated for publication. For Gavriela, the opportunity to take part in ongoing scientific research has enhanced her interest in a career in science.

The Science Research Mentoring Program (SRMP—pronounced "shrimp") offers New York City high school students the chance to join ongoing research projects led by Museum scientists. These research projects cover topics including conservation biology, evolution, genetics, anthropology, astronomy and astrophysics, and Earth and planetary sciences.  

For more information, visit the SRMP website: http://www.amnh.org/learn-teach/grades-9-12/science-research-mentoring-program

snippet.title: The Museum's Science Research Mentoring Program

snippet.description:
Student researchers in the Woodland Ecology Research Mentorship (WERM) program at Wave Hill discuss the research they have done, the coursework they completed to prepare them to do ecological research, and how being a WERM has changed their ideas for future careers.  

WERM is part of the NYC Science Research Mentoring Consortium.

For  more information, visit: http://www.studentresearchnyc.org
snippet.title: Wave Hill's WERM Program

snippet.description:
High school students in Columbia University’s BRAINYAC program talk about their initial impressions of working in a neuroscience laboratory, what it was like to carry out their research, and how their overall experiences in the lab have impacted them.  BRAINYAC is part of the NYC Science Research Mentoring Consortium.

For more information, visit: http://www.studentresearchnyc.org
snippet.title: BRAINYAC Students' Journey Through Lab Research

snippet.description:
After completing a two-year science research mentoring program at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, high school senior Isaiah Kitchings gains experience in the lab, confidence in his presentation skills, and direct exposure to the latest biomedical research.

In 2014, the Center for Excellence in Youth Education (CEYE) at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai established the Lloyd Sherman Scholars Program, a new and innovative biomedical science enrichment program that aims to prepare young men of color for careers in science and medicine.

The Program involves three components, beginning with a preparatory summer course in biotechnology and concluding with a laboratory research placement during the summer before senior year of high school. Throughout the two years, the program includes college readiness sessions, professional development workshops, individual and group coaching, academic counseling, and access to the faculty, staff, and resources at Mount Sinai.

The Lloyd Sherman Scholars Program is named after Lloyd Sherman EdD, the founding director of CEYE, for of his longstanding commitment to exposing underrepresented minorities and economically disadvantaged youth to science and medicine.

Learn more about the Lloyd Sherman Scholars Program: http://icahn.mssm.edu/about/diversity/ceye

Founded by the American Museum of Natural History, the NYC Science Research Mentoring Consortium is a group of New York City academic, research and cultural institutions committed to providing high-potential, underrepresented NYC high school students with mentored, authentic research experiences in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math). Our students, Pinkerton Science Scholars, are shaping the future of STEM. Learn more at: http://www.studentresearchnyc.org.
snippet.title: Mount Sinai's Lloyd Sherman Scholars Program
